review_text: The Kracked Pot is an experience and destination in it's own right. The building has so many unique features, for instance my "room" was a suite with a large sitting room that used to be the front parlor I imagine, the floor had an inlaid wood Greek Key design border, a piano, and leather Arts and Crafts furniture. My adjoining bedroom was also spacious with a big, comfy bed, the original tiled fireplace, a 1920's vanity, small frig and private bathroom. While decorated with antiques, art and lots of cool objects to discover, it is not cluttered, stuffy or fussy, it's a very relaxed atmosphere. There is a lush garden with a dream hot tub, best jets I've ever used. William's ceramic art is throughout the house and gardens, his work is unique, I was amazed and hope to buy some one day. There are books everywhere, and when I met Thad he was carrying a stack of them. All was super clean and well run, with thoughtful amenities and clear instructions on how to use them (which I missed reading on my first stay, but they are there ;) ). I could go on and on, but the best part was William and Thad themselves, like visiting wonderful uncles or cousins whom you haven't seen in a long while and you regret not having done so sooner. I could have just hung out at the house and had a retreat for several days. But I did go out and Lil' Washington is a charming riverfront town that feels like stepping back into simpler times where people wave and love to shoot the breeze, met some very nice people in such a short time, and there is a long boardwalk along the water to take an evening stroll. Looking forward to returning, you should definitely make a stop or stay awhile, an amazing property and wonderful people.

If you’re looking to stay downtown, this is your spot. The space is tiny, but perfect for an individual or couple. The amenities are extremely clean, the furnishings and decorations unique and eclectic. The owners ensure you are provided essentials above and beyond, from granola bars to sparking water in the fridge. The downtown location is perfect for any events Washington offers year round. Two downfalls, which are frankly out of the owners control but I feel need to be noted so future renters are aware :
1. Parking is limited during the day. Washington has small parking locations for the amount of day to day traffic that they see. Main Street parking from 10-7 is almost impossible, which leaves two options the back parking lot or the waterfront parking lot. Point to this comment—— expect to walk a distance upon check in.
2. A steep/narrow staircase is your entryway to the loft. Anyone with weight or health issues may have problems with this.

Mary Anne’s Original Washington “Caboose” is exactly the kind of place we look for when we play what we call “Airbnb Roulette.” We like to pick a centrally located place with a Super Host in an area we don’t know and use it as a base of operation to discover the locale. This place was perfect in every way for our needs and exactly what we think of as the ideal Airbnb property for the kind of travel we enjoy doing. We want to be close to the locals, and we want to engage in the community where we are visiting. Mary Anne’s place is exactly as represented in her photographs and narrative. It’s fun, a little off-center, and clean and well maintained. Tucked near a corner at the end of two streets, right by the start of the town boardwalk (currently being reconstructed…coming soon!), this is a great place to just park and walk the downtown area. The Town of Washington is a very interesting place to visit, with up-and-coming shops and restaurants. Do be aware that most of town is closed on Mondays, and with the current pandemic, many businesses are still not fully staffed and reopened on their regular schedules as of mid-June 2021.
Having said that, come here and check it out! This is the spot you’re looking for to relax, unwind, and embrace a slower pace of life. We did several out and back trips during our visit, including visiting other historic nearby towns. In addition, we made it to Nags Head and Kitty Hawk (Kill Devil Hill) to visit the Wright Brothers National Monument. Let us save you some time; avoid the “back” road of 264. It’s not worth the extra “scenic drive” time heading up. Just take 64 etc. (follow your GPS) up and back. It’s a long but interesting day trip and will allow you to put your feet in the Atlantic Ocean.
Local favorites for us were Backwater Jacks (amazing fried oysters), and Grub Brothers (solid fried green tomatoes and a very interesting okra johnny cake kind of thing...), with a great beer selection and solid food as well. Shep’s Grill was a very acceptable breakfast spot (and he says his lunch is really good too…), and Mary Anne recommended The Bank Bistro in one of her newsletters available in the Caboose, but we didn’t get a chance to catch them open. Several new places are coming soon, including Two Rivers Brewing, which looks like it will be a fun spot once it’s opened. There’s also supposed to be a very good gin distillery in town, but, again for us, we were not able to catch it open. Come and stay here or in Mary Anne’s sister property, The Sleeper Car, next door. You’ll be glad you did!
